intro: Bassia sedoides var. taurica, commonly known as Russian knapweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in dense, fluffy clusters, which bloom in late summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped, serrated, and often covered with a waxy coating, aiding in water retention. It thrives in dry, sunny environments and is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides.
